Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Novel Functionalized Nanomaterials for Effective Remediation of Spilled Oil Contaminants in the Gulf of Mexico
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:
This project uses novel materials to address an urgent need for de-contamination of petroleum products in the Gulf of Mexico. Petroleum is a mixture of several hydrocarbons, dissolved gas molecules, organic nitrogen compounds, organic oxygen compounds, organic heavy metallics, colloidal particles and several other products. A few volatile petroleum chemicals evaporate easily, while other chemical compounds that are easily dissolved in water remain for longer periods causing harm to all aquatic animals. So, keeping in view the complete remediation from organic contaminants arising due to the oil spill, this project investigates the integration of two novel materials such as bio-surfactants and photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants. The presence of the bio-surfactant will increase solubility of oils in water and could lead to higher oil degradation rates. The complete removal of organic compounds will be made possible by using a graphene-based photocatalyst nanomaterial. This de-contamination supports the cleaning of the organic products as well as organic-metals contaminants from sea water. This project also supports green technology because there are no residual products remaining in the sea water after the de-contamination process. More generally, this project stimulates students interest in de-contamination awareness and nanotechnology among the students interested in obtaining master?s and doctoral degrees on subjects related to both nanotechnology and remediation science.

TECHNICAL DETAILS:
After the catastrophic oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, de-contamination efforts include the removal of even trace molecules from petroleum products. This project works towards developing a better understanding of the complete remediation of all organic contaminants. It integrates two technologies for the removal of organic pollutants using the biosurfactant and photocatalysts-containing graphene (photocatalysts with large surface area nanoshells and graphene-doped photocatalyst with or without graphene) particles. The presence of biosurfactants could increase solubility of oils in water by leading to higher oil degradation rates, whereas the complete removal of organic compounds could be made possible by graphene-based photocatalyst nanomaterials. With funding from this Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID), investigators at University of South Florida, Nanotechnology Research and Educational Center (NREC) are examining the efficacy of removing oil products from sea water. This RAPID project is also examining methods and materials to clean organic products as well as organic-metal contaminants from sea water. The project is comparing de-contamination of water collected from different affected regions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project finds the integration of two technologies for removal of organic pollutants using the biosurfactant (rhamnolipid) and photocatalysts- titanium oxide (TiO2) containing graphene nanoparticles. The rhamnolipids being good biosurfactants have been used to remove organic compounds, whereas the organic compounds are completely remediated using photocatalysts based on graphene -TiO2 nanomaterials. The decontamination of organic including petroleum compounds have been decontaminated using synthesized G-TiO2 and G-TiO2-rhamnolipid nanomaterials using sol-gel technique. The use of rhamnolipid in G-TiO2 shows the improved organic remediation in both
UV-visible and visible light. This project shows the remediation of methyl
orange, toluene, naphthalene and diesel at different concentrations from water. The experimental findings under this project have shown the advantages of organic decontaminants using G-TiO2-rhamnolipid over G-TiO2 nanocomposite. The project also shows the experimental investigation of organic remediation from water using nanomaterials such as G-zinc oxide (ZnO) and G-ZnO nanowires. The project has shown the optimization of the synthesis of materials, slurry formation using nanomaterial, decontamination of organic from water as a function of time using UV and visible light.

Intellectual Merit:
This project shows organic remediation using our integrated technology based on TiO2 based nanomaterials with biosurfactant. The synthesis and characterization of nanomaterial were performed to understand the organic remediation. However, we understood that the TiO2 based nanomaterials and biosurfactant could be non-toxic material to decontaminate the organic from water. The G-TiO2, G-TiO2-rhamnolipid, G-ZnO and G-ZnO+TiO2 nanomaterials could be used for complete decontamination of water. Our proposed work has shown the remediation of 90 to 100 % of organic compounds such as methyl orange, toluene, naphthalene, etc.  From
water from UV and visible radiation of light. We have shown for first time how
the integrated nanomaterials could be able to remediate the oil from water. The presence rhamnolipid increases the aqueous solubility of oil, whereas the
complete removal of organic compounds will be made possible by photocatalysts TiO2 particles. The biosurfactant/TiO2-graphene is able to react with initially the organic to make it smaller suspension so it could be easily broken by the help of light particle.

Broader Impacts: 

Our integrated nanomaterials decontamination find great societal impacts of water remediation for all purposes. Our method and materials are well suited to completely get rid of the organics from water. The new structures will be developed to understand the first remediation using the nanomaterials. We have explored the new synthesis process for nanowires which effectively remediate organic from water. This research provided novel learning opportunities for students including under-representative students to understand the sustainability field of water remediation using nanomaterials. Dissemination of the proposed research has been presented to various conferences.
